column27: Colorectal Cancer Screening
No national program; limited access to colonoscopy; opportunistic screening in private sector.
No national program; limited availability of screening (mostly urban and private).
No national screening; awareness is low; limited access to colonoscopy.
Opportunistic screening in urban centers; no organized national program.
Pilot screening programs in some regions using FOBT; not nationwide.
No formal national screening program; opportunistic tests may be available in urban hospitals.
No national screening; highly limited infrastructure.
No national program; opportunistic screening with FOBT/FIT/colonoscopy in private sector.
National screening using annual FOBT starting at age 40; follow-up colonoscopy if positive.
National Cancer Screening Program: annual FIT from age 50; colonoscopy if positive.
Opportunistic and pilot screening programs in urban areas using FIT/colonoscopy.
Organized FIT screening for individuals aged 50–70 since 2018; colonoscopy follow-up.
National program using FIT biennially from age 50; colonoscopy as follow-up.
National bowel cancer screening for ages 60–74 (FIT every 2 years); Scotland starts at 50.
Organized program: FIT annually (50–54 years), colonoscopy offered every 10 years from age 55.
National screening using FIT every 2 years for ages 50–74.
Organized national program with FIT every 2 years (ages 55–75), with follow-up colonoscopy.
Regional programs with organized screening using FIT (ages vary, commonly 60–74).
Regional programs using FIT every 2 years (ages 50–69).
Regional programs with FIT every 2 years (ages 50–69).
National screening using colonoscopy starting at age 50; also FIT in some areas.
Opportunistic screening; growing awareness and use of FIT in urban areas.
Opportunistic screening with FIT and colonoscopy; some state-level programs.
National program offering FIT every 2 years for adults aged 50–75.
National program offers FIT every 2 years for people aged 50–75.
National guidelines exist; implementation mainly opportunistic or regional.
Organized screening with colonoscopy, FIT, or sigmoidoscopy starting at age 45; covered by insurance.
Organized screening programs using FIT or FOBT starting at age 50 in most provinces.
National Bowel Cancer Screening Program (ages 50–74) using FIT every 2 years.
National screening with FIT every 2 years (ages 60–74), being phased in.
No national program; screening is opportunistic and awareness is growing.
No organized screening program; very limited access to colonoscopy.
No formal program; screening extremely limited.
National FIT-based program implemented; colonoscopy for positive cases.
No national program; opportunistic colonoscopy screening in urban hospitals.
Opportunistic screening available in major hospitals; no structured national program yet.
No colorectal cancer screening program; infrastructure severely impacted.
Opportunistic FIT or colonoscopy in private hospitals; no national program.
Opportunistic testing in urban centers; pilot programs exist but no national policy.
No organized screening program; some NGO-driven and private hospital initiatives.
No national screening program; opportunistic colonoscopy available in major urban centers.
No national program; FIT/colonoscopy opportunistically
